characters: AND FINALLY RETURN TO WEATHERED HANDS STILL WASHING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark night.  Most street lights shot out.  Just one or tw the eerie vapor lights left on the block. A MIDDLE-AGED AFRICAN-AMERICAN MAN carries his single bag groceries.  The man listens and watches carefully, as he negotiates the darkness between the few pools of light on street. We won't see his face until he reaches the next pool of light, but he walks with shoulders hunched in fear. Moving down the block, all shops abandoned.  Broken windo Rats.  The man almost trips over a vague shadow passed ou and crumpled in an abandoned doorway.  It's the crackhead saw mumbling himself into the nod-off zone.  He's still faintly singing a part of the bones song as the man passe He stops in the light. And we see it's SHOTGUN: 20 years of fear and loathing et on his face.  He freezes, listening for a second to the crackheads wheezing mumbles - no - it's something else he listening for -- and hearing. From behind him a low wheezy sound, like some huge pantin dog.  He stops.  And it stops.  He walks on and it follow As he hurries to the next pool of light and safety, his e strain for the nearly silent padding and wheezing steadil following. Suddenly, he hears that panting closer and closer until i nearly right behind him.  He starts running, though he ha yet seen anything.  Only heard the mongrel hot on his hee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he stumbles, careens, and wheezes through the streets alleys, terrified.  Winded, he eventually stops, his hand trembling into his shopping bag, seeking a weapon. And we see the building he's paused beside: Bones' place. Pockmarked by age.  Like the face of some furious old man Now he can almost feel the dog's breath on the back of hi neck...Shotgun spins, whipping a bottle of milk out of th bag and hurling it into the darkness behind him. The bottle smashes against the wall of Bones' building. a second, silhouetted against the now whited wall, the ta too tall, shape of the skinny black dog. Without waiting to see what he hit, Shotgun takes off run to reach his building across the street.  The sound of th dog's nails skittering across the street right behind him -- and he just makes it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, safe, panting for breath.  Then starts running up stairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside his third floor window, we see Shotgun run i his apartment, slam down his groceries on the counter, gr an old rifle from under his bed and hurry to his open win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He scan/aims out his window across the street to the now desolate building where Bones once lived.  Finger on the trigger, eyes scanning the shadows for the dog.  Mumbling quotations from the Bible about canines, some of which ar handwritten and taped up on his walls and mirrors:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Thou shalt not bring a dog into the house of the Lord thy God, for they are an abomination."  Deuteronomy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, something moving on the empty street catches hi eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Dog emerging from the shadows in the street.  O first good look at the beast.  Long clawed paws, all teet and tongue and a curved bony rib cage like it hasn't eate 20 years. It's long black head seems almost to be throbbing, moving from within, almost subliminally we see a weirder, demoni more skeletal dog face just beneath the black fur... Or i just the buzzing light from the vapor lamps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he aims his rifle) "They return at evening: snarling like dogs and prowling the city..." Psalms 59, vs. 6...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog stands in the pool of light, offering a perfect s Shotgun smiles, aims, and then fires, making --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a direct hit!  But the dog doesn't move.  Unfazed.  Th bullet must have missed.  Or else gone right through him. The long-faced dog just looks up at Shotgun like it was laughing at the fool.  And has been for years. Shotgun reaches for the spilled groceries on the counter. Shoving aside bread and canned goods and other edible necessitates, and finds a half-dozen boxes of rifle round He calmly reloads the rifle.  And the sound of another sh echoes in the night over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two frat boys, JASON and PALMER, driving a too nice car i too bad part of town.  Palmer at the wheel while Jason ma a call on the cellular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Gun shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a backfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you'd know.  Face it.  We're lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a left, no, I mean a right.  Okay, stop for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in the middle of a block.  Jason on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here.  Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Back here.  At the end of the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns around and sees behind them, TWO GUYS standing o the far corner.  One's on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) You got the cash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone) Yeah, but you got to come the rest of the way on foot.  Leave your car and walk over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit the car, looking all around them with more than touch of paranoia. As they walk nervously down the block, they join the two the corner.  It's STANK and WEAZE, both 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands him the money) Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't carry it in my pocket, man.  And I can't go get it for you cause you might be a cop.  You gonna have to pick it up yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason and Palmer aren't sure about this.  By the sphincte look on his face, Palmer would rather forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  It's just round the corner.  Halfway down that block, you can't miss it.  Top step of the front stairs, there's a loose stone.  Go on, I ain't shitting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it.  Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk around the corner and enter a bleak block with least half the lots burnt out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it too late for me to officially register my growing certainty that this is an extremely bad idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farther down, in the center of one side of the street, st a particularly ominous abandoned building.  Bones' buildi Jason ignites a Zippo, and they see one loose brick.  Jas pulls it out and behind it sees a glint of baggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy as pie.  And twice as tasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the bag.  It's filled with rock cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE STREET
dialogues.text: On the third floor, Shotgun sits in his straight-backed c in front of the open center window drinking coffee, cradl his rifle on his lap.  Sees the frat boys picking up thei shit.  Then he looks out at Bone's 'tomb': Dark blank windows staring back at him; the building's fr door covered with broken vertical boards with jagged piec missing, looking almost like a jack-o-lantern's grin. Shotgun then looks back down at the boys below.  From beh them they hear their car alarm go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's screwing with the car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But from the other way come cops, in a plain wrap car, a reaching out and putting the spinning blue light on the r No place to run.  No place to hide for the boys.  They re for the door of the shuttered building -- and it opens!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo.  You two, get the hell away from there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they ignore him and disappear into the darkness insid the gaping maw of Bones' building. Shotgun shakes his head sitting back down, cradling his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the boys huddle in the darkness behind the door, waiting for the cops to pass. The boys look around the decayed Gothic interior lit only the eerie glow of the sodium vapor lights outside. What we last saw as the ornate 70's luxury lobby in Bones day, is now  a horror show. Walls torn and stained.  Mold grows in patches on the wal and ceiling.  Huge cobwebs hang.  The furniture's all bro A gnawing tearing sound makes Palmer spin: a rat sticks i head up through the rotted cushions of the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get the hell outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jason shushes him as the room is filled with the flashing blue light of the cop car trawling slowly down the street From inside they hear the sounds of a car door slamming a cop shoes walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck, c'mon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gropes his way in the darkness to a staircase.  Palmer right behind him as they slip upstairs, deeper into the gaping darkness of the abandoned building. While below them the door opens and cop lights and cop vo penetrate the gloom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...not going in there.  Waste o' time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw 'em go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And from the boys' high vantage point up the stairs we se the first cop walk in with flashlight drawn.

dialogues.speaker: WHILE INSIDE THE COP CAR
dialogues.text: All we see are two meaty hands unwrapping a wax-paper cov pork chop sandwich.  The cop, face in shadow, brings the ping sandwich up over his huge belly towards his face.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE BONES' BUILDING
dialogues.text: The frat boys hold their breath while rats run across the feet.  Jason slamming his hand over Palmer's mouth to kee him from screaming.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW
dialogues.text: The young plainsclothes cop steps deeper into the room, a shines his flashlight at the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: UPSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Jason pulls the reluctant Palmer further up the stairs, t the third floor as below them they hear the cop coming up Jason pulls Palmer through the nearest door and into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rotted remains of what was once Jimmy Bones' master bedroom.  The room he was betrayed and slaughtered in.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS
dialogues.text: The cop begins to head up the stairs.  Visible behind him down through the open front door, is the plain wrap car. older cop inside, mouth fulla sammich, loudly says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it!  No way they're in there.  Trust me.  I've been working down here twenty years.  No one goes in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch as the younger cop returns to the car, giving up And when he climbs in, we reverse and reveal who the olde cop is: LUPOVICH, the cop who helped kill Bones. But he's decayed and expanded into a Hank Quinlan-like mountain of corrupt cop flesh.  Too many pork chop sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get the hell outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From upstairs, the boys see the blue light of the cop car recede as the car pulls away down below. Palmer reaches for the door.  He wants out.  But in the darkness, he can't find the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme some light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Jason we see a shape, a shadow, a tall silhouette, man-shaped deeper darkness forming within the darkness. Jason lights his lighter.  And in the flickering we see behind him that this room now contains a portion of hell: It's not just the chipped paint and peeled rotted wall pa or the cracks and gaps in the broken old ceiling mirror. All surfaces seem to be a swirling, shifting pattern in w we can dimly and subliminally make out faces as if people were trapped on the surface of things.  Exactly like the glimpse we had beneath the world when Jimmy died... The floor, the walls, the furniture, everything in it -- out of the wracked and twisted devouring and devoured for of dead souls.  Their faces, hollow pleading eyes and how mouths visible like flowing grain in wood. And in the center of it all stands the dark silhouette of Bones, impossibly tall and thin, stretching malevolently across the room like a living shadow. But the boys don't see this as they're finding the door. see Bones shadow arching towards them while they fumble. Palmer finally opens the door to the sound of a deep rumb growl from the darkness on the other side.  And in the op door stands the black dog. They boys jump back.  But breathes easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a dog...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the black dog leaps up at them -- teeth flying right the boys' throats.  And in the flickering ghastly light w see its demon face breaking through. The dog sinks his long teeth into Jason's arm.  He flails drops his lighter, still lit, on the floor. As soon as he does, the dog releases Jason, and disappear fast as it appeared, back into the darkness. The two kids panic, Jason shaking and bleeding, looking around, waiting for the dog or something else to attack, seeing back through the doorway into the room from hell. Behind them we see that tall man-shaped shadow.  The Bone shadow is oblivious to the two frantic boys, intent only the small flickering flame of the lighter still burning w it fell against the lower wood paneling of the wall. A thin trail of black smoke as the flame barely begins to catch on the chipped lead-filled flammable paint.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS RUN
dialogues.text: And stumble down the hall away from the horror, while bac the room the Bones-shadow watches as the lighter flickers dies out.  Other than a slightly blackened spot, the wall unburned. The black shadow shudders in rage, arches back and hooooo in frustration, its mouth abnormally large.  The shadowy snaps in the direction of the boys -- ready to vent it's wrath, and for a subliminal second we see in the head, th hellish face of Jimmy Bones. The boys round the second floor landing and fly down the flight of stairs.  Jason's foot breaks through a rotted floorboard and for a second, it appears as though rotten hands are just below stairs, grabbing at his foot and leg. He yelps in terror, pulling his foot back as they continu towards the front door, the Bones-thing's woofer-busting roaring down from the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHEER INFINITE ADRENALINE RUSH
dialogues.text: Of pure horror and the desperation to survive drags the b off the stairs as they tear across the floor and hurl themselves out the front door into the night air... Jason falling and lying on the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street, Shotgun sees the boys in the doorway.  Then, as a nearly dead vapor light suddenly flickers and comes to life, the shadows created on Bones' building mak look almost like a demonic face. Gulping for air, laughing hysterically at their survival, frat boys pause.  Jason sits back on his butt, checking h wound.  The doorway behind them just a black hole in spac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bumping fists together) Damn, bro.  That was close!

dialogues.speaker: THEN SUDDENLY
dialogues.text: Something - it happens so fast we're not sure just what g sucks-pulls Palmer back into the black doorway hole. Jason, still prone, tries to crawl away but whatever got friend now sucks him in too.  His fingernails scraping al the stoop in frenzied desperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he hears the boys pitiful screams and whimpers from across the street, he leaps to his feet and tries to see the dark of the doorway across the street.  But he can on hear what is happening to the unlucky frat fellas: Moans and the sound of flesh torn, and swallowed, and the last dying screams.

dialogues.speaker: UP AND DOWN THE BLOCK
dialogues.text: The screaming reverberates.  Faces appear in some windows While in others, shades are drawn and the lights go out..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mumbling to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "For outside are dogs and sorcerers..." Revelation 22, vs. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears welling in his eyes that he angrily flicks away.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKING AT THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: It still has the shadowy look/shape of Jimmy Bones, now shifting again as the vapor light on the street sputters again, plunging the street into near darkness.  The body Palmer no longer visible below. When he looks back, the building seems just an old buildi again.  Then there's movement in an upper window, catchin his eye.  Shotgun sees the tall, shadowy silhouette. The figure is elongated, can't tell if it is a man, or th distorted shadow of a man.  It beckons to Shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN
dialogues.text: Just tightens his grip on his rifle and speaks as if the shadowy thing across the street could hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still mad?  Still want me?  Come on and get me.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHADOW
dialogues.text: Shakes its head.  As if it can hear him.  And again mutel beckons to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.  You can't.  You're trapped there.  Well ain't that too bad.  Ain't that just too damn bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 1-2. out of order to reflect the final film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the ghetto.  A thriving street.  Shops and apartments. Storefronts, newsstands.  Life in the hood. A sleek black Buick Electra 'deuce and a quarter' floats the avenue, Curtis Mayfield-style...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the fur-covered steering wheel: SHOTGUN, a broke-n bodyguard for the man in the back seat: JIMMY BONES - 28.  His street.  His world.  Cool, handsom respected.  Dressed very fly, but not excessive.  Long bl coat, black silk shirt, and matching wide-brimmed hat. His left hand sports a big diamond ring while his right h toys with a long silver razor, polished and oiled to perfection so that the long glinting blade can swing back forth, or lock into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones steps out from the car on to his street like a benevolent feudal lord or a popular Mafia Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- greeting and soul shaking every man, woman and child o the block: they display a mixture of fear/love and respec -- coolly taking down numbers in a notebook: soothing to losers, encouraging to the wary, tough with the welchers. -- and handing out a rare win to an astonished old man standing in his pajamas in the doorway of an old tenement

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't spend it all in one place.  Spread it around.  And shop local.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 13-14. out of order to reflect the final film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Pearl standing at the sink, scrubbing the blood st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on her, washing her hands, washing and washing them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hands, washing becomes time passing.  Years, decades, building and the surroundings decay... And still the dark skinny dog prowls the shadows.  Just one more reason we n longer see anyone walk the street at night. The 90's end -- And Bones' building stands worn and naked with burnt-out on either side.  And the street feels like a ghost town. In the evil colored light of the gaseous street lights, Bones' own shadow stretches and distorts across all three stories.  His shadow face filling a window.  As in and ar the building and out in the ruins on either side, the bla dog still walks.

dialogues.speaker: THEMSELVES IN HOT WATER --
dialogues.text: To the PRESENT. Pull out and reveal Pearl, skin drawn, eyes heavy, now 20 years older, washing her hands.  And then drying them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 26-31. out of order to reflect the final film.  This portion of appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two raging black screaming skulls engulfed in eye-scorchi fluorescent green fire: The decals on the front panel of a Gemini Executioner, a tech mixer.  Four hands at the controls.  Throbbing, shif twisted beats.  We're in a Northside dance club: Pull out to reveal BILL, 20, and MAURICE, aka Space Cowbo and Intergalactic Gangster of Love, 20.  The two boys DJ- They're accompanied by the crooning voice and dancing bod Bill's step-sister TIA, 29.  Bill's black.  Tia's white. Maurice is not of this earth. Bill's turntablizing: his hands dance between two competi style direct drive turntables tilted side by side, playin them like an instrument. While Maurice plays in and around and out of Bill's rhyth with his 6 top-loaded computerized CD players, the boys h the beat back and forth and up and down, building outrageously, till Maurice tips it over the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness gracious grande bolas del fuego!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The floor is jammed with underground dance scenesters, college students and spaced-out shoegazers tripping on Ketamine, dancing with their invisible friends. The bar's surrounded by a sea of hands waving money, demanding drinks.  Our boys are popular.  And the club is making a lot of green tonight. See someone checking out all the money, counting heads: PATRICK, 23, Bill's older brother.  The money man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stank and Weaze are cruising around in the frat boys BMW, laughing their asses off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live show's over.  And a chill mix tape plays while the b pack their gear.  Across the club, Patrick's arguing with club owner, MOE.  Just now handing Patrick a couple bills Patrick's not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys and Tia stumble out with all their equipment, loading it and themselves into Patrick's over-sized SUV.  Patrick right behind them.  They gather around to split t fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the bad news is we only made 25 bucks each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could that be?  The box was packed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moe's terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We practically paying him for the privilege of playing his club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what the hell's the good news?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just accelerated my top secret long term plan for our world domination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sqweeep.  We innerup this programme to bring you this special news bulletin -- (human teletype sounds) "Aliens from Reticula 3 have hijacked Patrick Peet and injected moly headcheese into his skull filling his entire brain cavity with cosmic slop..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was planning on waiting until I got the place cleaned out, but -- like the man says, carpe diem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick hands Bill and Tia each a flyer: The Restaurant Brothers Ill Bill and DJ Maurice -- a.k.a. The Space Cowboy Playing at Illibent.  Fridays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Illibent?  Who's club is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're ya talkin' about, OURS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick beckons them into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick pulls up to the abandoned lot next to Bones' building.  In broad daylight the building looks even stranger.  The lines don't matchup.  Weeds and broken gla rusted autoparts, and empty abandoned shopping carts in tangled heaps like ruins in the lot beside the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a damn graveyard round here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, this neighborhood is coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But just where the hell has it been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step up to the front of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.  That is the ugliest building I have ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.  I think it's... I dunno.  Something about it just buzzes me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be the after effects of that Reticular inseminoid encounter you had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick opens the door and steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Ill Zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The darkness broken only by sunlight streaming through gr windows reveals the decaying interior of the building. We can see now nothing's been moved since the late '70's. Old furniture, carpets, pictures - late '70's Gothic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it's cold in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's eighty degrees outside.  And it's gotta be barely fifty in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And damp, too.  Let's not forget damp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattaya think?  Can you picture it?  Over there the bar, and in here -- the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible...maybe...could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick leads them to the stairwell going up and down aro the old elevator cage/shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a great deal on it.  They couldn't give this place away.  Just dead meat stanking up their books for twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to the elevator shaft, no elevator in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last owner on the lease before the bank was back in '79.  Some dude named Jimmy Bones.  Empty ever since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice looks down the elevator shaft and gets immediatel dizzy, almost plunging to his doom - pulled back by Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Bones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you heard of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a local legend back in the '70's.  There was a song, Stagolee kinda deal: "This is the ballad of Jimmy Bones/Black as night and hard as stone..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born near here.  My dad's from here.  He never mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones!  How baddass is zat?  This is the place for us.  Patrick, you get platinum props, man.  Platinum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in the land of the blind the one eye'd are king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your problem with Crippled Dick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look around, this place is a dump!  Naw, it'd have to work to be a dump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta use your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "This is Patrick..."  (makes the sound of egg cracking, the sizzling as it lands in the skillet) "...And this is Patrick on crack."  Imagination, my butt.  Even the space cowboy can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Why don't y'all check out the rest?  I'm going downstairs and see if I can get the furnace fired up.  Warm this place up, you'll see.  It has serious potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potential toxic dump site.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mia, Bill and Maurice all climb the stairs as Maurice lig a joint with a little box of stick matches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man said just to use my imagination.   (takes a huge hit) Let's see...yeah, I get it.  Potential.  I can see it now.  The first major urban theme park.  Village Ghetto land.  Kinda like Legoland, but made entirely from broken glass, hypodermic needles and crack vials.  Totally E-ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep smokin', fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia checks out the second floor while Bill and Maurice continue up the stairs to the third floor.  Bones' old cr

dialogues.speaker: WITH BILL AND MAURICE
dialogues.text: Behind them, barely subliminal glimpse - a manshaped dark shadow within a shadow.  Bill feels a cold wind from nowh And hears a whispery sound seemingly carried in the breez

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't eh money.  It's the big fat floating what if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take him down to the storm clear.  Bury him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't hear that?  "Take him... " Something.  "Bury him" or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take who where?  What you smokin'?

dialogues.speaker: BELOW ON THE SECOND FLOOR
dialogues.text: Tia's checking out a bedroom.  Hears a light tinkling in closet.  She opens it: empty except a row of rusty metal hangers, holding the moldy remains of Bones old suits.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS IN THE BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Is there a flashlight, poking around.  Trying to find the metal knob to turn on the gas.  Eerie as hell down there. Out of the corner of our eyes we see a shadow moving, looming.  A scurrying sound and Patrick turns his flashli in the other direction: we glimpse a bloated rat. Behind him, the shadow we glimpsed grows, elongates.  Pat notes another door.  This one padlocked.  Sensing someone something behind him, Patrick turns with the flashlight. Nothing there.  But the Bones-shadow is behind him again. Again he feels something and again he turns the flashligh around: nothing. Except the Bones-shadow is again...behind him. Shaking it off, Patrick heads for the old heater, pulling matches to light the pilot as Bones-shadow stays behind h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones watches as Patrick reaches around the gas heater. Patrick strikes a match head, the Bones-shadow moves even closer to him as Patrick reaches in and lights the pilot. When Patrick steps back, Bones-shadow grows and stretches spreading like an ink stain, reaching across to where the pilot flame flickers. In profile, the shadow-mouth blows...but no breath comes The flame doesn't even flicker. Bones tilts his head back and lets loose an eerie bellow frustration in a subliminal flash we see a howling mouth, bigger than any human mouth, howling within the shadow-fa The sound echoes all through the basement rooms as Patric walks back upstairs.  He slaps a nearby plumbing pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on old pipes, groan all you like.  Just please don't burst.  That I can't afford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As disappointed in whatever he hoped blowing out the furn pilot would do, he steps into the rusted remains of the o elevator and the POV begins to levitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones' POV rises straight up as if still in a working elevator.  It rises and we follow up from the basement to empty first floor, past the second floor to:

dialogues.speaker: THE THIRD FLOOR
dialogues.text: Where we're still inside, floating in the elevator cage.  Then the POV moves through the metal bars and floats towa Bill, who's approaching the door of the room where Jimmy died. As Bill reaches to open it, Bones' POV floats closer - an closer - right up on Bill's back now.  Bill feeling the h on his neck suddenly rising.  Then he hears:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.  It won't kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill turns around to check with Maurice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had to hear tha...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Maurice is gone.  And he doesn't see the shadow there behind him.  Bill leans in to the door, listening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna be the only one with this nigger's blood on my hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the f--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand jolts him from behind.  He spins -- it's just Maur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'S up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Contact paranoia.  Must be buggin' from hanging with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to walk back down.  Maurice stops to re-light h joint when the Bones-shadow reaches out to grab his wrist But it's no good.  The shadow hand passes right through, Maurice pauses for an instant as if he felt something. Maurice lights his roach, and the match burns closer and closer to his fingertips.  Then singes them and he drops match.  Maurice then heads downstairs after Bill. The shadow remains behind, staring at the still burning m on the wooden floor.  He bends down, staring intently as willing it to burn, his hands urging it on, the flame suddenly rising.  But then the match sputters harmlessly The shadow turns back towards the boys downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: WHILE ON THE SECOND FLOOR
dialogues.text: Tia explores the rest of the floor.  Hears a sound, like whimpering, from behind another door. She slowly eases open the door then jumps back -- Inside, dog.  It growls low and mean, the black fur on the back o it's neck rising.  It's eyes burning too red and bright. Tia freezes. The dog growls deeply at her.  And as he does we see the Bones shadow rising behind her.  It seems to lean in and her, and the dog stops growling. Tia cautiously holds her hand outstretched with the burge for the dog to smell. Bones' shadow from lingers behind her, perhaps simply enjoying the first sight in hellish eons of a beautiful g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get locked in here?  And for how long?  Poor baby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog leaps up - but not to rip her throat out.  Instea snatches the burger and wolfs it down in one gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor boy.  You must be starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill looks skeptical, Maurice outraged.  Patrick firm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want us to move in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the only way we'll get the place fixed up in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah right, and which ever of us is still alive at the end of the week inherits all Vincent Price's cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you guys want to play college radio, high school reunions, and some fool's club once a week for the rest of your lives, that's cool.  But I think we can do better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You soundin' like the old man now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in you guys.  You are the real shit.  And you know it.  Now I'm putting everything I got into this cuz I think we can make it happen, but you gotta put a little in too.  Now all I"m asking is that everybody do their part.  We'll move some shit in, and take shifts, or all crash together here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat's right.  It'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine.  But Mars Needs Women.  If I gotta sleep in a spookhouse, surround me with chicks who are more scared than me.  Speaking of which...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia's coming down the stairs.  Maurice watching her legs appreciatively as she descends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rips Maurice's skull) Tia ain't a chick.  She's family.  And don't forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get going.  Go home, pick up what we need, then crash here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who I found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes in with the dog padding silently behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, that's the nastiest dog I ever seen.  Nothin' but skin and bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, call his skinny ass "Bones."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bones" grins, all teeth with its tongue hanging out.  Th walk out the front door, the dog slipping out with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotgun watches from the window as the group exits the building with the dog.  Seeing the cur he instinctively reaches for his gun.  But the dog's surrounded by kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watcha doing with that dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yours, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what do you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my advice.  And shoot that dog.  Or let me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  Yes sir.  Anything you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia, Bill and Bones the dog pile into the van as Pearl an her daughter CINNABAR, 21, walk by. The daughter's as fine now as her mother was then.  Pearl sees the dog in the van and her head snaps to the gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't feed that dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people really don't like dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some holes can't be filled.  Some hungers can't be satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (way under his breath) And some people need their medication tweaked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not joking boy.  Don't feed it.  It'll only make it hungrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl walks a little faster, trying to draw Cinnabar away from the kids and the dog.  But Cinnabar lingers a few paces behind her mother and catches Patrick's eye.  He's stunned, and before he can speak, Maurice speaks for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need any help with those bags, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: no really, let us help.  We're new in the neighborhood, gonna be neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You moved into this block?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really to live, just to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna be le hot shit.   (to Pearl) Pardon my Francais.  Dance club.  The Resurrection Brothers play there.  Heard of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they on the radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.  But they will be.  They're the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I manage them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you bought the building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl studies their faces, especially Patrick's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look mighty familiar to me.  You sure you're not from around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was born near here.  But after my mother died, my dad moved.  I grew up out in Rossmore Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty black to be growing up in Rossmore Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in front of a storefront - same old palm readin sign.  But the name is different.  Now it's "SISTER PEARL READER AND ADVISOR."  Pearl enters the building while a lingering Cinnabar catches a look on Patrick's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess it's not Rossmore Park.  Thanks for the help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anytime.  Be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick is still checking her out.  And we can see from a window, Pearl is still checking him out.  While Maurice i checking out the wacky window design.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well if she got psychic powers, how come she's working here on Desolation Row?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. BLACK CAT POOL CLUB - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run-down storefront, fronted by a crude faux-Parisian B Cat Facade.  A "private club", the local boss' HQ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the lights are dim and clouds of cigarettes and c smoke float over worn out old pool tables. Most of the tables are empty.  An older man wearing sunglasses lines up a careful shot on a corner table.  It Eddie Mack.  20 years after doing Bones, he rules the hoo What's left of it, anyway. Before he can shoot, Stank and Weaze breeze in, Stank hol some car keys up in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distracted, Eddie hits the eightball and scratches.  He s the pool cue over his knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit!  How many times I told you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a gift for you, Eddie.  Fresh new BMW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you stole off those white boys was down here last night?  Are you crazy?  Everybody from hell to breakfast heard that screamin' on Blackstone last night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times I told you, no psycho shit.  There gonna be psycho shit, I'm the one that does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't do nothing, Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gon tell me you didn't ginsu those punks and steal their ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all we did, steal their ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get that car the hell away from here, now!  I spend a lot of money to keep the cops cool.  But this is the kinda shit that pisses everybody off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more thoughts from your asses.  Or I will burn your asses and snort the ashes.  Hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guarded entrance to the gated community.  Bill and th others roll up to the gate in their van. Barney Fife pokes his head in the window and stares at 'e suspiciously.  They all "smile" back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, go on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been living here my whole life, and that hillbilly still has to check me out each time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's his job.  Keeping indesirables outta the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull into the huge multi-car driveway in front of th house.  Not quite a mansion, but damn close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids are all sitting around the kitchen, watching Tia some meaty concoction to feed the dog.  The dog stares at expectantly.  Jaws dripping in anticipation. An older, distinguished looking black man walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we see their father is... Jeremiah.  Though now a prosperous banker, twenty years ago he was the man who se Bones up.  He enters with NANCY, his white second wife, T mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not only do I have to feed the three mouths I got, and that bottomless pit they call Maurice, I gotta feed this stray, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of Jeremiah's voice, the dog looks up right him and unleashes a low, rumbling growl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh, Bones.  It's not nice to bite the hand that feeds you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you call that dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving on) Just what are you feeding him?  I didn't know we had dog food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't.  I used that meat you had in the bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia, that was the prime rib I was marinating for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at the dog eating enough beef to feed six peopl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 1-4. out of order to reflect the final film.                    EXT. FURTHER DOWN THE BLOCK - TIME CUT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones is back in the car.  Shotgun rolling on down the st and round the corner. Bones sees a young black man leaning into the window of a police car.  It's JEREMIAH PEET, Bones' right-hand man, trying to do business.  And make sure his three year old keeps from running into the street.  The cop in the car eating a sloppy sauce-drippin' pork chop sandwich, watche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold up S-G.  Give him a toot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah speaking low and rapid to the cop who says nothi just wipes his greasy lips on a handkerchief. Then Shotgun hits the car horn, which plays a James Brown style trumpet riff.  Jeremiah steps over to Jimmy's car.  Jeremiah's son cautiously following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Sup Jimmy B. Shotgun. (to his son) Get back on the curb!  Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go easy on Jay Bird.  I can remember when we was his age...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy makes eye contact with Bones, who motions he's go dollar for him.  The boy nervously takes it from Bones an then runs back to the curb under his father's harsh eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all arranged for tonight.  Eddie Mack's gonna be there.  And Offisa Korruptsky, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get about twelve and a half minutes.  Tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, Jimmy, there's big money behind this.  Not just big.  BIG.  Like big business big.  Big corporation big.  Big government big.  Our little acre alone'll net hundreds a thousands.  Nothing but net.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but net?  Could be a swish.  Or a muthafucking air ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One simple word, three little letters.  Yes.  That's all it's gonna take and we could move out of this dump, get the real deal.  Big houses, legit business...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your dream, Homes.  Not mine.  I don't want to leave this street.  Ever.  The status quo is totally cool with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I oughtta get there a little early.  For good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't need luck tonight.  I'm just letting 'em have their say before I say no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) Let me see your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that shinin' and "reader and adviser" mess.  That was your mama's bag.  I don't know about the readin' but you both can sure 'nuff advise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swats his hand) My mama's bag and my granma's bag, and a long line of mamas before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like mama needs a brand new bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his hand in hers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such fine hands.  You shoulda been a musician.  You got the fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strokes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left hand's the past.  Your right's the present.  And the future.  But it's not written in stone.  It's written in flesh and blood.  And flesh and blood will change.  See?  There's something here, a new line, right across your life line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be my clothes line.  No?  How bout my phone line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No baby.  I'm serious.  Cancel that meeting.  I got more fruit that needs checking.  Come home with me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you worry about a thing.  This hand's gonna be stroking the back of your neck tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls away, the little boy waves good-bye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) 'Cause you got all the status.  And I got nothing but quo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 48-49. out of order to reflect the final film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cop car pulls up.  Out the passenger side come two skin legs, followed by a bowling ball gut.  Lupovich...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the cop in the car) Wait here.  And don't touch my fucking sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lupovich makes his entrance and bellies across the club towards Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not your style.  Is it Eddie?  Killing off your customers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't killed nobody. (gives a menacing glance to Stank and Weaze) Shall I rack 'em?  Play a game, Lupe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No time for eightball.  I got your tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses a bag of crack rocks on the pool table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confiscated their whole stash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack hands him a wad of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough for the shit.  But I think a little bonus is due for knocking out the competition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You was just doing your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last thing you need's for me to start doing my fucking job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack hands him another wad of Bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's more like it.  Cost of doing business.  Maybe you can deduct it on your taxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JEREMIAH'S HOUSE - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick talking to the others, Jeremiah asleep by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we got a line of hundred paying guests and another couple hundred inside dancing, that's when I'll tell him.  And I can't wait to see the look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. THE PEET DINING ROOM - LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the table, Chinese food containers.  Tia's still sneaking meat to the dog under the table.  The TV on in t corner. Jeremiah's topping off his dinner with XANTAC -- high blo pressure medicine.  His normal dyspeptic mood not improve the conversation the kids are having.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you think crack got into the ghetto?  By magic?  Who flew it in?  Like the man said "we don't own that many planes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah increasingly uncomfortable with the subject matt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't poison your mind with that ghetto paranoia.  That's all just ways of people justifying their own failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, the man has been lying to us for a hundred years.  I mean, where is my forty acres and a mule?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't know a mule if it bit you in the ass.  And personally, I don't need a mule.  I got a Lexus.  And nobody gave it to me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV) There's a lead tonight in the strange disappearance of those two State College fraternity brothers.  There car, a 1999 BMW, was found abandoned this afternoon in an inner-city neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: We see flashes on the news of various streets of the hood including a shot of Bones block and building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 61-64. out of order to reflect the final film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah swears a painted smile on his face as he shakes just entered Lupovich's hand.  They seem, for all the wor like old friends as he leads him back to his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the minute they are in his office, Jeremiah's friendl demeanor drops like a mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a visit with my old pal, Jay-bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lupovich looks around the expansive office and paws the photos and knicknacks on Jeremiah's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You certainly traded up. (picks up a wedding picture nearby) ...the trophy wife.  Nice lookin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your hands to yourself, willya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been watching you.  You done good.  Invested wisely.  Respectable businessman now.  Just like you always wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?  Still a pig.  Just a much fatter one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason to get nasty.  Yeah, I've stayed in the organization.  But then again I never got the percentage you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or you didn't know what to do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe so.  Maybe so.  But that ain't why I came to see you.  You sold the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shit a shitter.  Our building.  What did you call it?  His 'tomb'?  We had an agreement.  You were supposed to sit on it.  Not sell it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't sell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, somebody bought it.  That's what I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire?  Could you come in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An assistant manager, CLAIRE, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did we sell any properties on... Blackstone recently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matter of fact, we did.  5606.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only met with the broker.  The structure was listed almost worthless and had never even had a bid, I thought you'd be pleased to see it sold to someone who wants to improve the neighborhood.  Anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not.  Good work.  Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.  Lupovich is still holding the picture of Jeremiah's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  One of my associates sold the building last month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a Bozo no-no.  Jay-bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, even if anyone found anything there, it's twenty years ago.  They could never connect it to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better hope not.  Cause it's like they say, four can keep a secret, if three are dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the photo with a wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice rack.  How old is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it.  Get out.  Now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah advancing on Lupovich, who chuckles and walks ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's stopped by a kick under the table from Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some terrible shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean your mouth, or I will.  Those boys had no business messing down there.  Go places you're not meant to be -- that's what you get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's your old hood, Pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and it took some doing to get out of there.  Just be glad I did and you can start life from here instead of down there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe we're the ones who should be down there.  Doing something.  Making it better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be done.  That place already died and gone to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 52-54. out of order to reflect the final film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF ANGLES - A MONTAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick cuts of the moon, the sun, Bones neighborhood, Patr and the gang cleaning up the building.  And finally, at dusk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick's on a ladder replacing glass in the upper window From down the block, we see Cinnabar heading out of her mother's house, holding her portfolio.  The corners of pa sticking out, splashes of color visible. Patrick sees Cinnabar about to walk beneath his ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful.  That's bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That place is already bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It goes way back.  Or so my Momma says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else does she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  You'd think she was crazy.  And she is a lot of things, not all of them nice, but crazy Momma's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way I figure, everything our parents tell us is part true and part total B.S.  And our whole job is figuring out for ourselves which is which.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My momma says every house is two houses.  Every street, two streets.  There's a whole city, a whole world, kinda beside, on top, just below this one.  The city of the dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like right now, there's actually like hordes of dead people shambling around us?  Fingers rotting off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  But there's an invisible wall, a fabric that kinda keeps things separate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But when something bad happens, something really bad -- the wall breaks.  The fabric tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dead get out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the living fall in.  Who knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you believe her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I did, I wouldn't come within fifty yards of your door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sees her bus pulling up at the corner and runs for it leaving only her smile with Patrick. She passes Maurice and Bill, pulling up.  Bill has to pul Maurice's dog like attention away from the way Cinnabar's bottom moves as she walks down the street to focus at the matter at hand: unloading their shitload of equipment. This portion of the screenplay contains scenes that do no appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice and Bill carrying speakers and racks and lights a turntables while Shotgun, in his lawn chair across the street, glares at them. After the last equipment is loaded, they lock the car.  Shotgun still watching.  Bill pulls out a six pack of bee He offers one to Shotgun who, after a beat, accepts it. Maurice surreptitiously turns on his small hi-7 camera.  Holding it under his arm, but it's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever hear of Jimmy Bones, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business is it of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wondered.  We heard he used to live in our building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotgun says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  He lived there.  And died there, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Died there?  How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell should I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones?  He was something.  He could be cold as ice or warm as blood.  But he never turned his back for a brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes drift up to the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice goes in.  Bill lingers behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my advice.  Get the hell out of there.  It's a bad place.  Always has been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Maurice walk around interviewing folks about Bon Bill with the DAT recorder, Maurice with the vidcam. We see this through Maurice's shaky video camera: grainy VIDEO SHOTS: An OLD WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and every Tuesday, he'd roll by in his car and drive me with all my laundry to the laundromat so I wouldn't have to carry the clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a dude in a wheel chair.  Drinking outta paperbagged bottle with a wino hanging on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Bones?  Yeah, I knew that motherfucker.  People make out like he was some kinda damn Robin Hood.  Bullshit.  I saw him cut some muhfucker's tongue once with that razor of his...dropped it right into that jar of dill pickles they used to have on the counter in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a kid he used to slip twenties into my pocket so I could buy toys and shit. (now to Maurice/at camera) Bones was awrright.  He was solid.  And then one day, he just wasn't around no more.  Don't pay to ask too many questions 'round here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upstairs, inside what was once Bones' bedroom.  Beneath t cracked ceiling mirror, Bill lies on the airmattress.  He listening with headphones to a minidisk player. Eyes closed, head nodding to the beat.  Around him, we se something strange.  The room shifts. It's the same room.  But changed.  It looks like it did w the frat boys were trapped in here.  Or in the instant af Jimmy's death: all surfaces seem to be a swirling, shifti pattern in which we can dimly make out faces, as if peopl were trapped on the surface of things. Then the faces and bodies begin to step out of their surf and into the room.   So as Bill, eyes still closed, rocks to the hypnotic beat his headphones, we see the room around him begin to fill figures. -- all twisted dead human forms emerging out of the surfa of floor and walls.  We hear a low murmur of ghost voices different languages. And as the track ends, the sound cuts through Bill's headphones and his eyes snap open. But the room is empty.  And completely normal.  Bill pull off his head phones.  Ears strain to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia?  Patrick?  That you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds return, fainter, and form above.  Bill looks u and for a fraction of a second in the mirror, Bill sees t crowded eerie hell of the other version of the room. Bill jolts out of bed and to the door, whips it open, and someone dark looms right there.  But it's just Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spooked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill looks back into the room, normal now.  Glances up at mirror, just a cracked reflection of the empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Well, yeah.  Maybe just a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there is a strange vibe here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops.  Both brothers look at each other, waiting for other to admit he's seen or felt something's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the others?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice left.  Tia's taking a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bathroom is entirely wood lined, like some '70's hot paradise.  The room dominated by a large two person tub. Tia lights four small scented candles on the counter.  Th wind through the open window blows the curtains.  She shu the window and then steps gingerly into the steaming bath She lies down in the bath, with her back to the door.  Th four candles throwing varying shadows of her. Then one of the shadows becomes...the shadow of Bones.  A it's attention is focused on one lit candle.  The one clo to the curtain. Slowly the Bones' shadow's fingers start to caress the curtain to make it move, ever so slowly, closer and close the candle.  The drapery reaches out, straining, strainin towards the candle flame. Tia soaks with her eyes closed, enjoying the moist heat. Bones' shadow fingers more and more urgently drawing the flame towards the curtain, the curtain towards the flame. And soon the corner of the drape just reaches the little flickering flame.  And in an instant the drape is on fire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Bill still talking in front of the bedroom, d the hall from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we just been in the damn suburbs too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their conversation interrupted by screams from down the hall... from the bathroom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drapes are fully ablaze now, flames lick at the woode walls.  Tia leaps out of the tub, screaming, trying to th bathwater at the burning drapes. Patrick and Bill crash through the door.  Patrick rips th drapes from the wall and throws them into the bathtub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia shivers in her bathrobe.  Bill and Patrick with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't any draft.  That window was closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all tired.  Everybody makes mistakes.  Tomorrow in the daylight, everything's gonna look different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladders, drop-cloths and the beginnings of new paint on t old torn walls.  They're all eating take out burgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were bringing the Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gangster of Love don't eat no fried chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  He eats everything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what army do you think the Colonel was in? (whistles Dixie) Everybody knows the whole chicken distribution network is owned by the Klan.  "Special recipe".  I'm telling you.  There's something in the batter.  Say it makes a black man sterile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bull.  Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word.  I saw it on Sixty Minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice, even if it was true, what are you worried about?  Last time I checked, you weren't black.  I'm not sure what the hell you are.  But I know you aren't a black man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the future.  I am all colors.  All races.  All creeds.  I am the melting pot.  I am the tossed salad.  I am post racial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post-toasted's more like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 44-46. out of order to reflect the final film.             EXT. SOUTH SIDE - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, angle on Bones' building down the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the building - we can hear sounds coming from inside t house.  Like dim drums, some kind of rhythm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the dog eats and eats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even CLOSER.  The sound is a little louder, a little more disturbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the dog eats and eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing now right in front of it we hear a rhythmic cacophony from inside, growing louder as the dog eats and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound is deafening.  It's the sound of every door in empty house swinging maniacally on its hinges.  Beating t air like wings.  Opening and slamming shut again and agai Every door except ONE DOOR.  The padlocked door to the su basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some older folks, one very old man with a cane, two old b women, arms linked.  A middle-aged husband and wife.  All enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dim light.  Cloth covered table.  Everything set for a seance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, brother.  Welcome, sisters.  Make yourselves comfortable around the circle.  We'll begin in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks upstairs to Cinnabar's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters the room where Cinnabar is drawing a still-lif assignment by a window overlooking the fire-escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to finish this for class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a vision, girl.  Just like I got.  Just like my momma had.  And the good Lord didn't give you that vision just for painting pretty pictures.  That's just wasted time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean as opposed to your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regrets it halfway out her mouth.  And a thousand-fol more when she sees the look on her mother's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Momma.  Maybe next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you meeting around that house.  You stay away from those kids.  And away from that dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seemed alright.  Bring a little life to that old building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but a wide world o' pain locked in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe once upon a time.  But that was long ago.  Back before... before it became what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a bad place.  And the doorway to worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar, as far too often, not understanding much of wha her mother says to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay contains scenes that do no appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.   INT. PEARL'S STOREFRONT - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl reaches into an old bureau drawer and pulls out an photo: Jimmy Bones with his arm around her.  She sits dow her table with a drink and just looks at the picture of herself and her lover when the world was innocent and you She downs her glass and wipes her tears away.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: In the upper window of the Bones Building we see his silhouette, staring down the block towards Pearl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones the dog slinks into the kitchen.  Sniffing the air. Still hungry.  Always hungry. His big black paw actually opens the refrigerator.  With long nose he digs into the meat drawer.  Inside he finds plastic wrapped raw hamburger meat. He pulls it out and drops it on the floor.  Tears it open gorges himself on the raw meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house looms malevolently in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones' POV again in his rusted elevator cage.  The POV fl down through the house into the basement.

dialogues.speaker: BASEMENT
dialogues.text: Bones' POV looks at the padlocked door.  Then passes righ through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the deeper darkness of the dirt cellar we see the Bone shadow hovering over a slight mound in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black dog wolfs down the last of the hamburger meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he does, the ground seems almost to breathe, or gl Bones plunges his long shadow-hands right into the earth if he could touch what was beneath and raise it up. He remains like that, shadow hands buried in the dirt, he tilting back and howling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotgun up in his window, still, holding his gun.  Hears howling.  He looks around, expecting to see his nemesis, black dog.  But only darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah's mansion stands in the moonlight.  Its faux Gerogian splendor in stark contrast to Bones' building in old neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is dark and quiet.  All are asleep.  The dog mo silently through the house sniffing at doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog silently noses the door open and stealthily enter and pads softly over to Jeremiah's side of the bed. Where it stares intently at the sleeping Jeremiah, who be to toss and turn.  He settles again on his back.  His hea tilted back, his soft, vulnerable throat exposed. The dog steps closer to the bed.  We can almost feel the dog's hot fetid breath inches away from his throat. The dog stares at Jeremiah.  And for just a second the lo doggy face wavers and changes: in shifting shades of blac ragged red demonic face ripples beneath the black fur -- looks for an instant as if it were about to lunge and rip Jeremiah's throat! But at the last second it freezes.  Head cocks and ear li as if hearing something in the wind.  Its master's voice, perhaps.  And then the dog reverts to normal and pads out the room as silently as it entered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 60-62. out of order to reflect the final film.  This portion of appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar stops outside the building.  She's about to knoc when she instinctively freezes.  We can almost see the ha standing up on her neck one by one. She looks around -- what is it?  A sound, like a moan.  I her name?  Or just the wind. Suddenly, with a creak, the door swings open. She takes a hesitant step into the building.  Suddenly sh jumps, as a door to her left flies open. It's just Patrick.  She laughs in relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thought I'd see if you needed any help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick too surprised and tongue-tied to respond, so Tia helps him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  We do need help.  First you can help us eat lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar follows Patrick into the room, with a last tense look over her shoulder -- still the feeling something's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia's feeding the insatiable dog.  Handing quarter-pounde to it, the thing scarfing 'em as fast as she can unwrap t Then, for a second, it stops.  And looks up.  And just st at something it knows is there -- but we humans can't see

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watcha looking at, poochie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar follows the dog's glance.  She sees nothing...or there something for a second there in the corner?

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Is staring back at her, and at the dog.  Cinnabar pulls h sweater around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate it when dogs do that.  Like they're looking right out of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog continues scarfing down burgers, having him his w Cinnabar looks warily at the beast.  Who stares right bac her while wolfing down the burgers.

dialogues.speaker: BONES-VISION/POV
dialogues.text: Steps through the rusted metal into the old elevator shaf and we follow it as it floats down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dog above eats we again see Bones' shadow form loo over the seeing dirt, the dirt moving ever so subtly, and a subliminal second the dirt seems to be glowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all painting.  Maurice spins some tunes to accomp them.  It's a funky Tom Sawyer paint party.  The kids def to Cinnabar, who's got a wild pallette, and a wild brush. The place is coming alive with color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay is originally pages 65-72. out of order to reflect the final film.  This portion of appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Bones' old room, Patrick rolls over the faded stained shag carpet with a huge carpet cleaner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The transparent tubes of the cleaner fill with disgusting fluid and carpet fibers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
