dialogues.text: Patrick stands back and surveys his work.  The carpet loo perfect.  Old, a little faded, but clean.  No stains.  With a smile of satisfaction he rolls the cleaner out of room and closes the door behind him.  We remain in the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The now clean carpet.  Suddenly we see glutinous red liqu seeping back up through the shag, until the stain is righ where it was.  Wet and fresh.  Then we see it spread and move, in the shape of a body and the path by which it was dragged out of the room. The door opens again, and Patrick steps in to show off th freshly painted room clean rug to Cinnabar and the others He's brought up short by the sight of the stain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be something seeping through.  From the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They roll the carpet back, thinking there must be somethi on the floor.  The floor beneath the carpet is wet too, b can't tell if it's from the rug or vice-versa. He puts his hand down on the wood.  A low rhythmic rumbli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others place their hands on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  It's.  Throbbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Like a heartbeat/Like a love beat."  Listen to the Di Franco twins there.  Just the plumbing or something, fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's a pipe underneath the floor.  It leaked and stained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a better explanation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and the others in the basement listening to some strange sounds: groans, thumps, throbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like we got the Invisible Scratch Piklz hiding in our pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick traces the piping with the wrench, he comes to a triple corner, where three small pipes all come together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think these bring the water down from the bathroom.  Into this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A larger pipe that goes down the wall and disappears bene the floor.  The thumping sounds emanate from here.  He pu his finger along the seam of the joint.  He pulls it away red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it out.  The same shit that was in the carpet.  Told you it was from the plumbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the wrench to tighten the seal.  The metal groan Then snaps.  Sending a thick spray of foul smelling red sludge shooting out of the seam, right into Patrick's fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, I knew these pipes were wacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns the wrench the other way, re-tightening.  The so seems to move now through the piping.  Then the red sludg sprays out of the next three joints, smearing the others. The pounding, throbbing sounds begin to bounce around the room, as if something were actually moving through the pi until it returns to the central large pipe and moves down disappearing beneath their feet. Then a rasping bark calls their attention.  Bones the dog sits by the padlocked door, panting.  Grinning. Patrick smashes the old lock with the large wrench and op the door to reveal another set of stairs leading down int deeper storm cellar where the sound disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go, the temperature drops.  A cold, damp sheen appears on their skin.  Then comes a thick glutinous buzz sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flies.  The stairway walls are thick with furry black fli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping) Ugh.  Muchos moscos, man.  This is too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some flies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some flies?  I think this qualifies as way more than "some."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what you expect?  Where there's smoke there's fire.  And where there's flies, there's shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stairs end in a dark, damp dirt cellar and the remnan of the terminus of the old elevator shaft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I guess this would be that space that was so perfect for a recording studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice, man, shut the fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, Maurice is right.  It's gonna take more work than I thought.  But we can still do it.  We'll lay a real floor in here.  Put damping on the walls.  Totally controlled sound.  Be perfect.  No one could hear shit up on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind them the dog is digging in the dirt.  Furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, perfect.  Really excellent.  We can make our first record where no one can hear us scream.  Be afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not paying any attention to the dog's incessant digging.  Only Cinnabar is.  She's staring at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she sees, in the deepening muddy hole at the dog's pa at first glimpses and then the full view, a rotted human corpse.  Really just a skeleton.  With something sticking of its chest.  Cinnabar shrieks, while the guys try very to act real cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.  Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maurice bends and pulls out the now blood rusted razor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boys and girls, Moms and Dads.  Children of all ages, I'd like you to meet... Jimmy Bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) "This is the story of Jimmy Bones/Black as night and hard as stones/Gold plated deuce, like the King of Siam/Got his switchblade loose, and a diamond on his hand..." There's the switchblade and there's the diamond.  Don't know where the deuce is parked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to one of the bony hands.  The left one.  On th third finger is Jimmy's big diamond ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that's really him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.  It's so...fresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's right.  Oddly for an old skeleton, there are str and bands of wet, raw flesh.  Maurice lifts the hand wear the ring.  He starts top pull it loose from the finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, put that thing down.  You can't take that.  Might be evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidence of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow I don't think he stabbed himself in the chest, then buried himself too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar sees something.  Bright color beneath the body.  Bends down to a piece of cloth poking out from beneath th bones. The dog growls viciously as she reaches down to the scrap color poking up.  Tia restrains the hound the best she ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your damn dog, girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cloth is the corner of a dress...the dog suddenly lun for Cinnabar's hands, ripping at them.  She pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!  Damn dog.  We gonna have to do something about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we have to do is call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Call the police.  We'll have no problem getting our permits then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't just leave it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can.  Least till after this weekend.  He ain't going nowhere.  We'll deal with it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever, let's just get the hellout of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all start to leave except Maurice and Cinnabar.  He' loitering by the body, eyeing the ring.  She's staring in the dark corner of the sub-basement.

dialogues.speaker: THE DIM LIGHT
dialogues.text: She sees something wavering, a shadow-mirage, Bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh yeah.  Coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows the others upstairs.  Bones watches her form she climbs the steps, and -- -- for a second from BONES POV we see her mother, when sh was young. Bones looks now at Maurice.  Who checks to see if the oth are gone.  Then Maurice hurriedly bends down, and while holding his face back away from the stench attempts to pu Bones' ring off his finger.  But it's stuck. He tugs again, harder, and rips the corpse's finger off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh fuck is right.  Bones' shadow rears as it sees this desecration.  Maurice slips the ring off the finger stump

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the corpse) Sorry, but you wont' be needing this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places the finger back by the hand.  And pockets the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tia fills a bowl with dry dog food.  But Bones the dog tu his head away and just whimpers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picky mutt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out a package of raw hamburger, dumps it into t bowl, then leaves.  Behind her, the dog tucks into his ch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lock broken, the door stands ajar.  And as the dog go upstairs, something very strange is happening down here. Flesh is growing on the bones.  Bit by bit, red, wet stri of muscle and flesh appear and spread over the corpse. The shadow looks down at his semi-reconstituted corpse. almost looks like him, minus the skin.  But it still has long ways to go.  Still, mere strips of muscle and flesh the skeleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her usual small crowd arrives for her seance, all hoping will be the night they reach their loved ones' spirits. outside, through the window, we see Pearl greet and seat of them around the table.  She starts lighting candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Cinnabar sipping a little Remy in his room.  Alone at last.  Awkward.  Intimate.  He refills her glass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't want me here.  With you.  In this house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, my old man'd rupture his spleen if he knew we was down here.  All he talks about is the medal he deserves for building us a life as far from this 'hood as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably thinks he's saving you from something.  I'm sure that's what my mother thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure I can make your mother like me.  But then do I gotta worry 'bout your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly their banter is dead.  Her face looks stung, lik he'd slapped her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know anything about my father.  I never met him.  Momma won't talk about him, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arms around her, and she melts into him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl and the others seated in the dim room around a circ table.  They are holding hands.  Only candle light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should begin with a hymn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Bones' old room, the temperature between Cinn and Patr goes from PG to R. The two kiss passionately, deeply -- Cinnabar loses herse for a long beat -- then as if swimming up from the bottom a deep pool, she pulls herself back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.  Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.  If you want to go home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I want to stay with you guys.  But I can't.  I mean I'm not ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.  I'll stay with the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From outside, through the open window, we can hear the strains of singing coming from her window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We float around the members of Pearl's circle.  See objec on the table flickering in the candlelight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spirit world is all around us right this minute.  And the departed are pressing in around us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still singing, they all glance about them in darkness as they can make out the spirits around them. Over the low bass of their hymn-singing, her voice cuts i Uncoiling and rising like smoke in the air: it's a beauti voice and it does seem to open a window in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar gets into bed and turns off the light.  Pitch da in there, can't see a thing. As she's drifting off to dreamland, she hears what sounds like the door quietly opening and someone slipping into t darkness of the room, we just stay on her face.  It's cold in the place.  And spooky.  So she doesn't mind when she feels what she assumes is Patrick slip in bed be her.  Though we see only a shape sliding under the covers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-asleep) It's okay, just don't get funny on me.  It's warmer this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the curtains fly open.  And Pearl's voice sudde stops... and the flame on the candle shoots up, scorching ceiling before returning to normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone's with us.  Who's joined the circle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lordy...what's that smell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  The flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flowers whither.  They retch from some smell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock once for yes.  And twice for no.  Is there someone who wishes to send a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table rocks once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A message for one of us in the circle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table rocks once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it for miss Lillian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table rocks twice -- "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a message for Mr. Abernathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table rocks twice -- "No" again.  She goes around the roo inquiring for each of them.  Each time the table says "No Until there is only her left.  An eerie pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the message for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table starts bucking wildly.  And suddenly Pearl's ne SNAPS back like it's been caught in a whip. Her mouth opens and a low moan escapes.  But sounds nothi like her voice.  A deep wind through an organ tube with swarming bees and squealing hogs mixed in. Everyone around the table just stares at her in alarm. As her eyes widen.  Go super close on her eyes and we see reflection in her pupil, not of the room she is in, but t Jimmy's building twenty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT with her face back in the seance staring wide mouthed in her trance. The sound of her heart pounds like the deepest dub track. Total dislocation for her as she sees Jimmy's old room, a was -- but also sees it as it is now, and with her daught Cinnabar, lying underneath the covers of the big, round b And lying close beside her, another figure beneath the covers. Whoever is there snuggles closer to Cinnabar.  She respon as he presses against her, then wakes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing low) Cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he doesn't.  The movement beside her is undulant.  Strong, erotic, she almost gives into it.  And still laug as she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no Patrick.  Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figure in the bed presses urgently against her, in a rocking movement which catches her up in it.  She can't h it, she begins to respond to the urging behind her. Pearl's eyes widen as the whole room shifts and becomes o fetid Necropoliptic texture.  The bed retains its shape b liquefies, seems to become one with the floor and the wal all made of a kind of thick, bloody-mud in which the trap faces and distorted limbs of the dead twist and moan. Meanwhile, on that strange bed, the figure behind Cinnaba seems to wrap soft limbs around her, locking her in embra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it doesn't cut out.  It builds.  Strong.  Erotic.  Insistent.  She almost gives in to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no Patrick.  Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the movement is more insistent.  And rougher.  She st to protest louder when she feels a hand, or something, st across her mouth to muffle her objections. Pearl tires to reach across her vision to grab her daught and help her, but she can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the seance, Pearl's back is arched like a bass fi string bowed, and then drops.  Released.  Back in her cha The instant she's returned to herself she's out of her ch and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar struggles with something in the bed, the covers pulled tight against her face, she can't scream.  She twi and wrenches herself about, finally striking behind her w a flailing fist, twists her face free and screams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick!  Stop!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room the door suddenly opens -- it's Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: AT PATRICK'S FEET
dialogues.text: The black silhouette of the DOG slips out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar looks wildly around the room -- she's alone in t big bed.  No one attacking her.  And she sees Patrick in doorway.  But then who - or what - was in the bed? Suddenly, her mother yells from below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar lurches out of the bed over to the window.  Down below, her mother's going nuts at the entrance, pounding the door and practically running over Bill who's opening door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outta my way, boy.  Cinnabar?  I'm coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you hang on and I'll see if she's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know damn well she's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar races down the stairs with Patrick, bewildered a her heels. Cinnabar runs out the door and straight into her mother's arms, burying her face in the protective bosom of her mom Pearl wraps her frightened daughter in her arms and turns to home.  Pearl looks up at the boys standing stunned in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might as well just dig down six feet of muddy earth and sleep in your own grave than stay another night in that house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns back towards her place, still holding the sobbi Cinnabar.  Bill and Patrick stand stunned in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure got a way with women, bro.  What happened up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned if I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up on a ladder, the boys put on the finishing touches and then HANG a new NEON SIGN over the door.  Looks pretty co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  We're in business. INT. JEREMIAH'S CAR - LATE AFTERNOON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading south on Lake Shore Drive, a tensely smiling Patr in the front seat with Jeremiah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?  You know I hate surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little business move I made.  On my own.  I think you're gonna approve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heading off the main road into the ghetto.  But as they h further and further south, Jeremiah's getting uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you always said, Pop, look for the undervalued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they are on the old street.  As they drive down the street, Jeremiah's getting more and more agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They park and get out.  He looks up and down the street, oddly frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you didn't even know your bank owned the place.  I did it through a broker so you wouldn't know it was me.  I couldn't wait to see your face when I fixed it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the building.  Freshly painted, with the neon sign. Jeremiah's face shows nothing like what Patrick expected. Nothing but a horrified, angry disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of sick joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah's so angry he almost smacks Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, boy.  I didn't work all my life to get out of this neighborhood for you to move right back in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be psyched.  Just trying to do what you did.  Take nothing and make something out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one'll ever come here.  Shut it down.  Don't worry, the bank'll buy it back.  I'll take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take care of it?  Not this time.  No way.  I bought it fair and square.  And we open tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit!  Bullshit!!  You're selling it back!  That's an order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah is furious out of all proportions.  Some of the others on the block have stuck their noses out to see wha the fuss is.  Then Jeremiah comes eye to eye with Pearl, standing across the street, watching, worried out of her mind.  Then he looks up and sees Shotgun in the window.  Feeling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: trapped, humiliated.  He wants out of this street.  Out o those glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all are coming back to the house, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody moves.  Jeremiah walks back to his car and pulls a Patrick, frozen, turned to stone by rage and hurt and sha Another car pulls up.  Several young people inside.  They look around a little dubiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I think we're lost.  You guys know where Illibent is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look at each other.  Silent.  Until Maurice answ by flipping a switch igniting the neon sign for the first time.   Illibent shines in brilliant blue gas letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE BLOCK
dialogues.text: The deuce and a quarter stops in front of a storefront. young Nefertiti in platforms and dashiki picks fresh frui and vegetables from the small grocery.  PEARL VAUGHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull over.  I'll walk the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl's picking ripe fruit.  Jimmy steps in, catches her hands, and the melon in them, in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, all wrong.  First, start at the belly button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strokes his thumb over the end of the cantaloupe, lean in to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta be an in-ey and gotta be smooth.  If it's ragged, it was picked too soon.  Won't ever be ripe.  Second, it's got to have just a little give, here.   (his hands on her hips) At the edges.  And last, but not very far from least... (now only a breath apart) You gotta get your nose in it and give it a gooooood, looooong sniff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know whether to chill you and serve with cottage cheese, or rip you open and eat you right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She chooses the latter, they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy's walking Pearl home; an apartment above the storef of her mother's fortune telling business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Baby, I gotta TCB this evening.  So come over 'bout eight.  We should be finished by then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy arrives home to be greeted on the steps of his buil by soul shakes and black hand fives from the corner boys hanging out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow Bones into the lobby with people waiting to see hi for favors, etc.  Rooms on either side, doors open allowi us to glimpse his crew, taking orders over the phones. An old fashioned metal cage elevator, with an equally old fashioned operator waits to take Mr. Jimmy up to his pad. ride up with him, the king in his castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator lets him out in his main room.  A '70's love pit.  Mirrored ceiling, circular bed.  Thick shag carpeti Jimmy nods at Shotgun, who lowers the needle into classic vinyl groove of some prime Funkadelic ("Nappy Dug-out"). Jimmy splashes cologne on his face and looks contentedly the window at all his people, at his kingdom below...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop we saw with Jeremiah, LUPOVICH, and the wannabe player EDDIE MACK (wearing an old Superfly suit, and slee black driving gloves) pull up in front of the old stone building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotgun mixes drinks at the bar and hands them to the jus arrived guests, Jeremiah, Officer Lupovich - looking stif plain clothes - and Eddie Mack in his purple suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Jimmy, you know Eddie Mack, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we used to do the after-school b ball at Kenwood.  What it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Officer Lupovich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones says nothing.  Just nods at the cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a nice crib here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do alright.  Everybody's happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But things change.  You gotta think ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got lotteries all over now, Bonesy.  Coming here too, maybe next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones' look sez: Bitch, don't call me that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half our old customers are gonna be getting their people to cross state lines to pick up lotto tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, there's more money to be made in the gin than the juice.  What do anybody want with numbers anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?  Money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't the money - it's the high.  The big fat floating 'what if?'  And it's way more profitable.  Nobody ever wins.  So you never have to pay out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a two dollar bet is cheaper than a twenty-dollar bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I ain't talking horse.  I'm talking about a five-dollar kick in the head that's a quick ticket to heaven.  And the fools keep coming back for more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those 'fools' are my people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no big thang.  It's just a po' man's free base.  Here, check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pulls a little rock of crack out.  Jimmy takes it i his hand and sniffs it.  Then shrugs and hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't interested.  And if you gonna sell it, don't sell it round here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.  It won't kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back off, Huggybear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like this, Jimmy.  There's a wave coming.  A big ass Krakatoa, East of Java wave.  And either you gonna be on top of the wave up there in chocolate heaven, or you gonna be buried 'neath the muddy undertow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cool.  Totally wide-screen sci-fi.  Forward thinking.  I respect that.  But that ain't my life.  I'm here and now.  Comfortable as a bed bug on a cold night in a warm nappy dugout.  I'm maintaining.  That's what it's about for me.  And your twelve and a half-minutes is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy just walks away from him.  Meeting over.  Eddie and Lupovich and Jeremiah all look at each other, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Let's go, Loopy-Lou.  Jimmy ain't into it.  Gonna skip the money train and take the bus.  His loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lupovich turns but then spins back around with a .45 in h hand and it's pointed at Jimmy's forehead.  Jeremiah didn expect this - or did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody just be cool.  Jimmy, man, I think you oughtta hear the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to hear the deal.  I don't need any partners.  I don't need new product.  And I sure as hell don't need this motherfucker's 'mattie in my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just try it, Jimmy.  That's all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands him the rock.  And a little pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the man.  Try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones keeps his eye on him as he lights the lighter and t a deep puff.  Then lets out a deep cloud of smoke. His eyes go a bit glazed.  And from his POV we see the ro start to tilt on its axis as everything goes wobbly. Just then, the door opens and Pearl steps in, distracting Lupovich for an instant. In one eternal crack fueled fast-and-slo-mo second: Jimmy sees his chance, he pulls his razor, but too slow -- Lupovich turns, the razor no more than lightly slices his arm, and he pulls the trigger on Jimmy Bones... Pumping three shots into Jimmy's abdomen, knocking him to ground.  Shotgun grabs his gun, but too late.  He's cover

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't worth it, Blood.  Just drop it.  And kick it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl in screaming shock.  Her lover bleeding on the carp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her to stop screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones is bleeding, and still tripping bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said stop that bitch screaming or I'll spread her like butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shotgun gently puts his hand on Pearl's mouth to quiet he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking down he sees his own blood pouring out, a thick divine river of many colors.  Looking up, they all stand wavering above him, hungry demons, their voices distortin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get his razor.  I ain't gonna be the only one with this nigger's blood on my hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack plucks Bone's silver razor right out of his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the gloves off.  Everybody leaves a print.  We hang out together.  Or we hang separately.  Cut him.  And cut him good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie pulls his glove off and enjoys himself as he shoves razor into Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it is?  What it will be, muthafucka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cut him, or I shoot you.  Make your choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah gets down near Bones.  Bones stares right into h eyes, as his life blood pours freely, weakly lifts his ar his best friend's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jay bird...help me...like brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah feels Lupovich's gun behind his head.  Hears it cocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

As he sees this, his (and ours) POV chang becomes darker, yet clearer; too sharp, razor sharp as so softness, perhaps life itself, drains out of it.  Bones s his best friend Jeremiah and Lupovich together dragging h body out the door, leaving a thick wet stain behind him. We can hear Jimmy's last wail of rage twist and distorts the air, becoming another deeper voice within the voice.. And then he (and we) plunge back down to the ground, righ the dark, wet stain in the carpet... Hit it and go down through an instant's glimpse into the black sea beneath the foundation of the world: Necropolis.  Where space itself seems to be made of pale bloated, gnawing, writhing things.  Bodies perpetually devouring themselves and each other. We see through this dog-eat-dog nightmare, back out throu the blood stain as through a key hole slowly closing.

His body sha and shudders spasmodically as the dog feasts on his liver Patrick starts for Maurice but the dog growls to keep him back away from its precious food.  Patrick backs up a ste Almost out of his mind with terror.  He really loses it w the dog, in SLO-MO, looks up and directly at him. Growling low, it begins to shudder uncontrollab to bulge and ooze. The room is filling with smoke. Bill's helping those trampled in the rush to get out.  Bi himself bleeds badly from his neck. Patrick runs with Cinnabar and Tia toward the door.  And the smoke fills the room, through the haze we see: Bones step into the room.  His arm raised with the razor. And he flings it out, like a boomerang, the razor flies around the room. It swoops down through the smoke at the remaining kids, hacking at them through the smoke, like some savage bird, though it doesn't seem intent on slaughtering them, but rather herding them out.  Bill and Patrick pull Cinnabar Tia out the door -- they're the last in the room. Suddenly the razor stops, freezes in mid-air and zips bac into Bones' waiting fist - just like a boomerang. Razor held high, Bones advances on them, steadily, cool a ice amidst the now fully burning house.

Sirens wail as fire trucks pull up and the men start unrolling a hose.  But freeze at the cocking of the shotg

dialogues.text: Jeremiah drives his still shocked and silent brood back t safety behind the gates of Rossmore Park.

dialogues.text: I don't want any of you ever back down there again.  You hear me?  And this time you'll listen to me.  Or I'll let them throw your asses in jail.  I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got his hands.  Beautiful hands.  I didn't even know.  That night.  When they - we - killed him, that you were already alive inside me.  Life's like that.  Grows right out of death.

dialogues.text: But if it's him.  If he's really come back, won't he know us?  Love us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, if it was really him.  But it isn't that simple.  Jimmy's body died a long time ago.  And his soul is long gone, and all that's left is that ravening, hungry spirit in the blood that soaked into the house itself, I suppose.

dialogues.text: But how do you know?  Maybe he just wanted to see us?  And now he's gone again.  And you've all killed my father for the second time.

dialogues.text: The building is finished, just a blackened shell.  Remnan of the staircase lead up to fragments of the upper floors Smoke still billowing from the empty center of the ruin. Silhouetted in the smoke and the low light of the rising a tall, dark figure, not of then, nor quite of now. It is Bones.  Taller, thinner, darker and more menacing t ever.  But unmistakably Bones.  He steps out of the rubbl And looks across the street, up at Shotgun's lit window.

dialogues.text: Shotgun's hand shakes as he pours another shot.  Then dow it.  He turns to the window and freezes at what he sees. Bones face is just outside the window.  The second story window.  Smiling in at him.  Shotgun is petrified.  But t he picks up his gun and shoots at the face in the window.

dialogues.text: Free at last, free at last.

dialogues.text: Shotgun whirls and there stands Bones behind him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't my fault.  I didn't know what they'd planned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shush.  It don't matter now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Really, Jimmy.  Remember, man.  It's me.  I was on your side.  Don't you remember?

dialogues.text: He just walks towards the terrified Shotgun, closer and closer, leaning right over his shotgun, his face coming j inches from Shotgun's face.

dialogues.text: His big brown eyes fill Shotgun's vision, and in what now seem to be the gigantic pupils in Bones' eyes, Shotgun se the old apartment, and there it all is again and again. Shotgun sees himself hesitating, almost risking it all an instead giving in, stabbing Bones -- he can't look away.  Then Bones closes his eyes.  Shotgun sobbing now.

dialogues.text: You coulda died with me.  Died trying.

dialogues.text: Shotgun is cradling his weapon, hands shaking.  He points at Bones and pulls the trigger.  Bones doesn't even flinc the pellets rip through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones' impossibly long fingers hold his long rusty razor. waves the razor in front of Shotgun, the rusty blade swin free back and forth, hypnotically, with a rasping sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then in one swift motion, on the back stroke, Bones' and razor slash across Shotgun's throat. Shotgun doesn't even have time to scream, we just hear hi breath and blood escaping from the new opening across his neck. Bones bends down and cradling his old friend, whispers ge into his ear.  Singing, perhaps.  We can't quite hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you on the other side, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones gets up and moves around the room, standing before window and looking down at the neighborhood he used to ow For a second he sees the old neighborhood, everybody hang out.  Then he blinks back to reality.  He looks down the block and sees Pearl's reader and advisor sign.

Patrick's in the bathroom tending the bloody scratches on back and arms.  He's frightened.  And angry.  He storms o of the bathroom, down the hall to his father's office.

dialogues.text: As Patrick slams the door behind him, Jeremiah hides a st of papers and photos beneath a pile on his desk.

dialogues.text: Did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, son.  I went down there and torched the place myself.

dialogues.text: You could have had it done.  You didn't want us there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't have risked killing you to get you out.  I was trying to protect you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah can't answer.  But Patrick's not leaving it alon

dialogues.text: Why?  Why did you give a shit about the building?  Why did you care that we were there of all places?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's...it's a bad neighborhood.  As you can see now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, Dad.  Don't front me.  For once.  Just tell me the truth.  I came from there, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were just a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw your face.  You knew that place.  You knew those people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the past.  It's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead?  I don't think your past is dead.   (points to the bandages) It's alive.  And it bites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night we see a walking shadow.  The long tall black Bones.  Heading down his old block.  Alone. As he moves, his face changes, at times demonic and inten But periodically that shifts as if a mask slipping off to reveal a similar but different face below.  More human, l pained, confused, and we see why:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark and desolate street he walks down keeps flashing brief instants into the street of twenty years ago. One moment, people nodding to him, waving, blowing kisses And then suddenly, it's the empty burnt block it is now. Bones' face shifts, cracking, one second the hungry ghost The next, he's the old Bones who once ruled this 'hood. He sees, down the block, the old palmistry sign.  It's Pearl's place.  For a second, the face of the real Jimmy Bones triumphs and he smiles.  Then hears voices behind h Stank and Weaze.  They see a tall, thin figure in some ve fine looking, long duster.

dialogues.text: Looking to score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unh-unh, little brother.  I got a natural high.  A supernatural high.

dialogues.text: (sorta singing) Big Bad Eddie Mack?  Got shit for brains and that's a fack.  Hey-heh...

dialogues.text: Yeah.  But he got a baaaad coat.  Whataya say, bro?  I check out your coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, out from the depths of his shadow, flies the ed of Bones' razor and the blade slashes Stank in the face.  Cutting a sideways, smart aleck smile in his cheek. Weaze pulls a gun and shoots Bones.  Bones jolts a little the bullet imbeds itself in his stomach.  But he takes it like a punch and looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut that shit out.

dialogues.text: He grabs one of the boys in each long hand and hoists the to his height and pins them against the wall.

dialogues.text: You tell my old friend Mackie, I'll be seeing him.  Soon.  Real soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wh-wh-whooo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This portion of the screenplay contains scenes that do no appear or occur elsewhere in the final movie.  In order t integrity of the screenplay, it has not been edited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearl sits alone, drinking.  Maybe crying a little.  Her hands shuffle large tarot cards.  She lays her own spread First card face down.  Second card face up. THE LOVERS. And across it the third is laid: the crumbling Tower. Then she slips the first card, the down-turned card out a flips it face up.  Death.  Suddenly a long black shadow f over the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Welcome back, lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finally looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so bad.  You're not quite him.  But you're not the shaggy demon I expected, neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face quivers and we see from his POV: Pearl - then and now.  Again, then and now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look confused.  The dead often are.  'Course, so are the living.  Take me.  I been confused a long time.  Least twenty years.  Maybe if I hadn'ta walked in at that moment.  Or maybe if I hadn'ta let you go at all.  I figure one way or the other, I killed you.  So it's only fair: kill me, lover.  I don't mind.  I'll even help you.  The way you helped me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs his hand, tries to stab herself with his razor. But he resists.  Pulls his arm free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?  That mean there's something more left of you than just that hungry spirit?  What are you going to do now?  Kill us?  Kill us all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Not...not you.  You I forgive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurls herself at him.  Slapping him.  Slamming her fi against his shadowy chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me?  The hell with you, Jimmy.  Cause I don't forgive you, I don't forgive you for dying.  And for being so goddamn stubborn.  Or for haunting my dreams.  And I don't forgive you for anything you're about to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at her.  His face wavering between the true face of Jimmy Bones and the angry Bones ready to kill her Then he wraps his arms around her and they kiss.  She fai the cards in her fist fluttering to the floor. He lays her gently down.  When suddenly Cinnabar throws t door open. She and Bones make eye contact.  She sets eyes for the fi time on the father she's never known.  And in the blink o her eye, he's gone.  She runs to where her mom lies on th floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stank and Weaze with Eddie Mack, who's getting a manicure from a coke whore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys been hitting the pipe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Eddie.  It's just that, I dunno.  He was tall, and thin, and like a shadow, his face was just a blur.  All I remember is the voice.  It was smooth and low and it didn't seem to be comin' out of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how'd you hear it, fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just like in my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I oughta open a couple holes in that head and let all them voices out.  You'll feel better, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Eddie, man.  Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's not about to shoot him.  He leans over and snort line of white powder off the mirrored tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to lie to me.  Now what the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (needs a hit) What about me, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shutup, bitch.  Now what, he just said to tell you what?  He was back?  Who was back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the very sound of the name, Mack freezes.  Then with sudden coke-fueled ferocity, he whips around and starts smacking the shit out of Stank, breaking his nose.  The c whore cheering Eddie on.  Wanting to see more action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones?  What the fuck is that supposed to mean?  Get the fuck out of here.  Both of you, 'fore you hear my voice up in yo' head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar pours some bourbon into a coke for her mother. Pearl just grabs the bottle and takes a straight hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll kill them.  He'll kill every last one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie Mack, that cop.  And Jeremiah.  And even when he's done, who knows.  He won't be satisfied.  Just like that demon dog.  Feed it, and it just grows hungrier.  Feed his hunger for revenge - he just wants more.  Who knows where it'll stop.  That kind of hunger ain't never satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you gonna do something about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?  I got a little power, sure.  A touch of the shining, a little of the sight.  But no more than you do.  We're not witches.  I can't wiggle my nose or say a magic word and make him go away.  Besides, maybe they deserve it.  Maybe we all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.  Patrick doesn't.  And his brother and sister don't.  And they're in the house with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (long beat) Fine.  Maybe I got nothing to lose.  'Cept you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are low and only the glow of the jukebox and t sounds of Harold Melvin and the Bluenotes as Mack and his manicurist get down on the pooltable, beside an ornate mi laden with two gold '45s and an ounce of cocaine.  Which are both doing to excess. Mack's wearing nothing but a black hat and black satin br (not a pretty sight).  Working now on her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones, my ass. (sings while unbuttoning the manicurist's blouse) "...if you don't believe he's laid to rest/You count the holes in his motherfucking chest..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tickles.  I want to hear that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her sashay to the other room where the juke bo is.  Then bends over the mirror to do a new line. From the other room, the song changes.  A deep menacing rolling funk number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, baby.  Gimme the rolling bass and I'll tickle your tweeter all night long...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Baby's" standing wide-eyed next to the jukebox, staring Bones, his razor pressed against her quivering lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack's wondering where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks doing a little funky Rufus Thomas shuffle to the music.  He steps into the club room.  It's dark, lit only the jukebox.  But it's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch.  Nobody walks out on Eddie Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he sees something.  Her legs on the floor, sticking behind the jukebox.  He walks towards her, slowly... Then sees the deepening pool of blood pouring across the floor right towards him.  Whatever happened to her, she's beyond his help now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Muthafucka!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whips around but can't see anyone.  He strides defiant back into the pool room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  I take you all on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack picks up the two gold plated revolvers off the mirro with coke on it.  Suddenly all the coke moves on its own. The many grams piled there, all merge into one pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bends down to check it out.  And the coke actually fli straight up off the mirror with the force of a punch and shoots like a fire hose straight up his nose. He reels back, choking.  Coughing.  After having probably ounce fly straight up his snot-locker.  Blood pouring out nose.  Wobbly now. He hears a low echoing laughter through the club, and the sound of the cue ball breaking and sending pool balls spinning 'round the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones stands by the pool table, under the overhanging lig He pulls out his razor and with one savage slice, splinte the pool cue in two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones?  Jimmy Bones?  That you?  You're dead.  I killed you and I stuck your dead ass in a hole in the ground wrapped in nothing but your bitch's bloody rags.  Now I'll count the holes in your muthafuckin' chest.  And I'll add a few more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fires both guns at Bones, while backing away.  Bones d feel a thing.  He just picks up the mirror and holds it u facing Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This it?  Your big-ass tidal wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack sees his own terrified face staring back from the mirror, belling hanging over his briefs, coke and blood clotted on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look like the wave's long gone and nothing but oil scum, dead fish, and yo' ugly ass left on the beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack shoots wildly at Bones.  At the mirror - blasting it into shards. But Bones stands unscathed.  And the shards of broken mir do not fall to the ground.  They remain in the air, formi living room swarm of razor sharp glass. Mack turns and runs, waaaaay too fucking late, as the swa of glass shards fly like angry wasps right at him Eddie's thrown forward by the sheer force of them, and is skewered throughout his body by all the glass fragments.  Pinned -- face mashed against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mack's voice) "I'm taking a five dollar kick in the head that's a quick ticket to heaven."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mack pinned to the wall.  Bleeding from everywhere.  Snot blood-coke mess drips out his nose.  Bones pulls Mack's h back by his hair and slides his razor into the half inch between his Adam's apple and the wall. As the juke box changes song, we hear a liquid slice and scream slip into a gurgle. Bones' long hands drip blood as he ties something to his belt.  We don't quite see what it is, not until we catch sight of Eddie Mack's headless remains pinned to the wall

dialogues.text: Lupovich is at his desk, finishing off a huge Polish saus Talking on the phone.  A cop named SAL is nearby, tidying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it.  The old slaughterhouse. (hangs up) Hey, Sal.  That little weasel we popped today?  He's got something for us.  I knew he would once he thought about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, that was fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12-year olds.  They scare easy.  Anyway, he's gonna tip their stash.  Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on my way home.  Can you handle it yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no.  Please don't make me go by myself.  I'm scaaaaaaaaaared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' comedian.  See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones walks the night with a slicing stride.  His legs stretching too far and somehow covering long distance in instant.  And in slo-motion, like a nightmare, marionette walking shadow, or some great black grasshopper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if swinging back and forth) Bones!  Bones, you muthafuckah!  What the hell you done to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones stops for a moment and looks down at his waist and see Mack's severed head tied to Bones' belt.  Severed, ye seemingly alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not half what I'm planning on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This some sick fucked up shit.  What you want with my head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just using it to carry your soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My soul?  Fuck you.  Look, I killed you.  You killed me.  Fine.  Now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones got no time to argue.  He bends and picks up a hand of fetid city garbage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we're even.  No need to get all meta fucking-phys-i-gack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And shoves it into the still talking mouth of Mack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright, loud summer night.  Blues coming from inside a bl bar, the guy playing "Killin' Floor". Lupovich heads toward the Armor building.  From a distanc he sees a young runner emerge from a passage on the farsi of the building then set off to meet his mark.  Lupovich heads for the passage, the music following him. Lupovich looks around to make sure no one is watching.  T slips into a passageway leading to the old slaughterhouse A scary walk through inky darkness, scattered with broken glass and scurrying rats and lit only by the eerie red li spilling like blood out of the open door into the old slaughterhouse at the end of the way. Lupovich reaches the back, right next to the old loading where the still-livestock were unloaded.  He enters the d disappearing into the red darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room, large and open, soaked in the sodium vapor that streams through the tall windows from the streetlights. There are a few blood rusted meat hooks still there, back hanging from the ceiling.  Graffiti covers the walls with arcane tags and symbols.  The floors are caked with a sti grime turned black in the orange haze. In the far corner burn three red votive candles.  Behind candles lies a crumpled brown paper bag.  The stash. Lupovich starts over to the corner, twitching at the gros sound of his shoes sticking to the layers of old coagulat blood on the killing floor. Behind him, framed for an instant int he doorway - a tall sharp shadow, a walking razor - Bones! The walk is tense.  Somehow the music has followed him he and is echoing and wailing in the walls around him.  He g to the corner, and reaching over the candles, opens the t of the paper bag.  Jackpot.  Five ziplocks of the rocks. He hears a noise.  Lupovich fumbles for his gun and at th same time reaches to snatch the stash bag.  His wrist tou the candles flame and it burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!  Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears another noise, a blade scraping on concrete, rig behind him.  Now the music blends with the echoing squeal the hogs once butchered on the cutting line. Lupovich hears another noise, a blade scraping on concret right behind him.  Now the music blends with the echoing squeals of the hogs once butchered on the cutting line. Lupovich turns and there, towering over him, stands Bones And just as startling, there's Mack's laughing severed he swinging from his belt. Lupovich can only choke on his terror, and while his mout open, Bones shoves a glass pipe into it. Brandishing his razor, Bones packs a rock into the bowl a torches it.  He holds the razor to Lupovich's throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Mack's voice) "Just try it...go ahead...it won't kill you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lupovich, trembling, takes a massive hit of the crack dee into his lungs.  The music and the sounds of the dying pi attack him as the coke fills his lungs and then his blood then his brain, his eyes starting to bug. Bones then knocks the pipe from his lips and seals his ha over Lupovich's mouth and nose.  He can't exhale.  The so get louder, the grafted walls come alive. Bones removes his hand revealing Lupovich's nose is fused shut, and his mouth is simply gone, the skin flat where t mouth used to be. Lupovich's gotta lung full of crack, and no way to exhale Severed Mack laughs insanely as he sees Lupovich's eyes b as his lungs start to strain under the agony. His frenzied suffocation is nothing but pure torture.  Wh he is still kicking with the fear and the drug rush, Bone drags Lupovich to the middle of the room. With one arm, Bones lifts the fat cop up and hooks him to of the meat hooks above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Lupovich's voice) "I ain't gonna be the only one with this nigger's blood on my hands..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lupovich squirms, Bones takes his blade, and shoves it just below Lupovich's sternum.  And a spray of blood pain Bones and Mack's hanging head. Thick crack smoke emerges from the wound and floats, fogl out of the chest cavity.  Bones then yanks the blade southward and slices the cop's belly wide open. We hear Lupovich's guts spill out on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that really necessary?  Can you wipe my fucking face?  I can't see a goddamned thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dope smoke wafts in the room four feet off the floor. The song immolates itself.  Blood drips.  And Bones adds another weight to his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just round the corner from the entrance to the gated subu Cinnabar and Pearl.  On foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to sneak in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No we won't, Momma.  I'll just have them call and tell Patrick it's us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl, they build gates like that to keep people like us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar walks up to the guard at the gate.  He picks up phone to check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone rings.  Patrick grabs it.  But his father's already the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) A young lady to see you.  A Miss Vaughn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Sorry.  Send her away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rent-a-cop hangs up the phone and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I call?  And talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  But not from here.  Nearest public phone would be back a few miles.  Outside the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar sees it's useless to argue and walks away.  Shoc and hurt.  Back to where her mother stands in the shadows outside the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you so.  Alright.  We tried.  Let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother!  No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear a voice from the other side of the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinnabar?  Walk around the north side.  There's an opening there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they sneak around the other side, a dark figure steps right up to the main gates. The rent-a-cop wakes up fast when he sees Bones standing front of him.  After all, how often does he come face to face with everything he is there to keep out?  He hitches his belt best John Wayne style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help y--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but then he notices the two-severed heads swinging fro Bones' belt.  All three of them smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can Jeremiah come out and play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other outer edge of the sub-development.  Patrick lea them in through some bushes and behind some of the pipe a power systems of the subdivision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why couldn't you just tell him to let us in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My old man calls the shots.  He built that gate and these damn walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cinnabar) You sure we oughta save him?  Why not just let see how safe his gates and walls keep him when his past comes calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save him?  What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremiah locks the door to his study.  Then he pulls out stack he hid on his desk.  A dusty manila envelope.  Insi photos: the old days.  His first wife.  His first life. in the old neighborhood.  Him and his best friend Jimmy B as children, teenagers and as adults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, brotha!  What it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Bones stands right behind him.  Severed heads hanging from his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What it will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time like this, is that what you really want to know?  How I got the fuck in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car drives up to the gate.  But no guard comes out to c it out.  The driver of the car honks.  But no response. Just the aimless squawk of the radio in the booth.  Can't really see into the tooth.  The windows are splattered an obscured by deep red stains.

dialogues.text: Patrick runs in with Cinnabar and pearl, past a startled Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His study.  Who're your friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they run right past.  Though Pearl gives a kind of ha wave 'hi-hello.' Patrick runs down the hall to his father's study.  The do locked.  From the inside, he pounds on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?  Open up.  Dad??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Tia stick their heads out to see what all the ra is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  We got to get in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill and Patrick slam against the door.  Finally it gives and they both tumble through the broken door into the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's empty.  Jeremiah's not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strange, greenish fog up and down the street emanating the burnt out shell of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High in the center, where the master bedroom once was, we a kind of mirage forming.  Another image of the room stil there, vaguely, luminescent in the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't go back there.  Are you crazy?  You saw --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only way.  It's possible your father may not be dead yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around at the mess in the room.  Over turned ch Signs of struggle.  Spatters of blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father was his best friend.  He loved Jeremiah.  So he must hate him the most of all now.  He'll take his time.  But even if it is too late.  If your father is dead.  It's not over.  The door has to be closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, close the fucking door by all means.  But don't expect me to go down there and do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up to go.  Cinnabar stands too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't going down there.  Not alone.  I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  But I'm bringing a couple of friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps out of the room and comes back with a gun and a knife in a sheath on his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't do you no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill with a defiant "well, it can't hurt" look.  Nancy appears in the doorway as they hurry out, seeing Bill wit the gun in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  I've just called the police and 911.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we need to get out of here.  We can't try to explain this to them.  We'll be back.  Hopefully with Dad.

dialogues.text: Nancy clings to Tia as the rest of them hurry down the ha
